hints.content: First, let's find the length of each pencil.

All of the pencils begin at $0\text{ in}$ on the ruler.  So, we can look at where our pencils end on the ruler to find their length.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: Four pencils are measured against a ruler. The ruler extends from 0 inches to 6 inches. Each inch is labeled and the space between each inch is divided into 4 equal sections by 3 evenly spaced unlabeled tick marks. The pencils measure as follows: pencil A measures to the first unlabeled tick mark after 5, pencil B measures to the second unlabeled tick mark after 4, pencil C measures to the tick mark at 4, and pencil D measures to the third unlabeled tick mark after 3. !

hints.content:
We can compare a ruler to a fraction bar.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A close up view of a ruler shows the space between 3 and 4 inches divided into 4 equal sections by 3 evenly spaced unlabeled tick marks. Above the ruler is a fraction bar divided into 4 sections of the same length as the sections on the ruler. Each section is labeled one-fourth. !

hints.content:
We can use equivalent fractions and label the ruler in simplest form.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A close up view of a ruler shows the space between 4 inches and 5 inches divided into 4 equal sections by 3 evenly spaced tick marks. The tick marks are labeled moving from left to right as follows: 4, 4 and one fourth, 4 and one half, 4 and three fourths, and 5. !

hints.content:
$\redD{\text{Pencil A}}$ measure $\redD{5\dfrac14}$ inches long.

$\blueD{\text{Pencil B}}$ measure $\blueD{4\dfrac12}$ inches long.

$\greenD{\text{Pencil C}}$ measure $\greenD{4}$ inches long.

$\purpleD{\text{Pencil D}}$ measure $\purpleD{3\dfrac34}$ inches long.

Now, let's graph the measures.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line plot labeled lengths (inches) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 3, 4, 5, and 6. Three unlabeled tick marks appear in the middle of each labeled tick mark. Dots are plotted as follows: 1 dot above the third unlabeled tick mark after 3, 1 dot above 4, 1 dot above the second unlabeled tick mark after 4, and 1 dot above the first unlabeled tick mark after 5. !

question.content:
**Measure the length of each pencil to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{4}$ inch to collect data for the line plot below.**

[[☃ image 1]]

**Now record your measurements on a line plot.**  
*Click above the line plot to make dots for each of your $4$ measurements.*

[[☃ plotter 1]]

options.alt: Four pencils are measured against a ruler. The ruler extends from 0 inches to 6 inches. Each inch is labeled and the space between each inch is divided into 4 equal sections by 3 evenly spaced unlabeled tick marks. The pencils measure as follows: pencil A measures to the first unlabeled tick mark after 5, pencil B measures to the second unlabeled tick mark after 4, pencil C measures to the tick mark at 4, and pencil D measures to the third unlabeled tick mark after 3. !
